Hello everyone. Welcome to today's Let's
Chat where we're going to be diving into
the development of UEFN. So, our goal
today uh with this live stream is to
give everyone a sneak peek behind the
curtains of how the tools are developed
and uh how feedback, bug reports, and
feature requests are taken into
consideration and prioritized. Uh we're
going to start off with some
introductions. So, for those of you that
don't know me, I'm Rubik. I'm a member
of team Bullseye. I've been developing
games in Fortnite Creative for over five
years now, and I'm going to be the host
for today's live stream. I'm also joined
by two team members from Epic Games,
Andrew and Jay. And I'll let you two
introduce yourselves. Uh we'll start
with Jay.
>> Uh hi, my name is Jay. I'm a product
manager working on UFN. I've been at
Epic for three and a half years, been
making games for over 22. And my primary
goal at Epic is to make sure that UEF
has the capacity to make games and that
making those games is is fun and
enjoyable.
>> Yeah. And uh I'm Andrew. I've been at
Epic for about 10 years. uh and lead
development of UFN and many of the
associated features. I've been in games
a long time and uh that's that's about
it.
>> Awesome. So, uh if you saw the original
announcement for this live stream,
you'll know that there were submissions
for questions and we got quite a few of
them. So, a lot of the questions I'm
going to be asking today are actually
coming from the community. Uh if you did
miss that though, you can uh send a
message in chat. just put uh the word
question before and then we're going to
have moderators actually keep an eye on
the chat and then at the end we'll ask
some of the uh extra questions then. So
um you don't have to worry about me
reading the message because we got the
moderators. So uh you only have to type

let's get into the first uh first couple
questions here. So I just started off
out with some uh general questions. Um
uh obviously you guys introduced
yourselves and kind of what you do uh
but what does the uh product team look
like as a whole here um outside of uh
the roles that you guys do?
So we have uh it's a little hard to to
firm numbers because Epic is very sort
of crossthreaded like we collaborate a
lot of different teams whether it's the
team who build battle royale or Unreal
Engine but focusing on UFN and things
like creator portal we're a couple
hundred people and we're organized into
groups one group looks at UFN and the
features versus APIs gameplay features
we have a team who look after things
like career portal and the publishing
features and uses and health and then of
course the community team who interact
on a day-to-day basis. So, uh yeah, we I
say fair fair count would be about um
you know 200 250 dedicated people who
really focus on the foreign ecosystem
and then of course we have the ability
to pull in other teams and support
across Epic where necessary uh things
like moderation and trust and safety for
example as a global uh global function
that we work closely with.
So uh when it comes to the tools, do you
have a separate team for like bug
reports or uh like adding new features?
How does that get divided? Then
>> it really depend it would really depend
where the feature is going to live. Uh
so we are UFN is obviously based on
Unreal Editor. So a feature that's going
to be very editor focused like scene
graph for example uh that's carried by
the Unreal editor team. So they are
building u uh features for UFN such as
scene graph and expanding the
capabilities of scene graph through the
editor as part of their their road maps.
When we look at things like devices
whether it's a general gameplay device
or perhaps something like the IP program
we have separate teams who are who have
their own road map and are looking at
our goals community feedback u potential
collaborations to try and understand
like where the best where the best
places to deploy resources are. And then
we have a number of teams who focus on
things like tooling. So literally the
workflow that has forums turn into bug
reports and internal ticketing. We have
a team that support that and and again
they have their own road map for
deciding how we can sort of best balance
the needs of development for against
user value.
So is it uh a lot of team decision or
coming to decisions as a team with
regards to the prioritization there and
would you say
>> we we typically we typically try and set
very high level goals for epic and the
individual products like every year we
have a list of must succeed uh like
things that we really want to see
succeed. So scene graph example was a
must succeed for this year uh things
like the persona device must succeed.
Beyond that teams get a lot of freedom
to kind of as I call it color between
the lines like we were saying that we
want to have like scene graph out this
year and the team that operates scene
graph uh the developers
can talk to community can look to bug
report as not bug report as a forum post
uh talk to internal developers and just
try and strike the right balance uh like
do we focus on something like
uh you know gameplay abilities or
gameplay attributes or atomization like
where where's the right balance to get
something out? where we kind of focus on
having meshes in the scene graph or UI

calls and of course things get bubbled

high five that we've we've picked the

Epic we're always kind of looking at
that road map and then did we make the

that we're not a company that believes
the the plan we set out whether to start
in 2025 is still the right plan midway

goals. So, it's it's fluid, but um you
we start with some very rigid plans and
then the team get the ability to
execute.
I think I'd even give it a good example

that came out to the community that

from the bottom
Absolutely. Yep. I uh definitely have

I think it's a combination of impact and

of um test players is really good uh
high impact and relatively little low
effort. Obviously we you know we don't
have people at Epic who are just sitting

it's like this is high impact like we

the aspirational uh I I'd like a

ecosystem maybe not as valuable. So we
we do that calculation and and sort of
try and understand like
is our plan the right plan or do we
actually look at this feedback and and
bring that in and be willing to move
things out.
>> Absolutely. Yeah. Jay, do you have
anything to add there?
>> Yeah, like the lens the lens that I use
formally is going to be repeating what
Andrew just said is does it bring the
community value is one of the first
lenses. Second, um do we have the

to use? Can the community use these

and take some of the short-term pains in

no, we're going to let you have the

pieces so you can do what you want to do

>> Awesome. Yeah. Um, all right. So, we'll
move on to the next question then. This
one actually comes from the community.
Uh, how far in advance are updates
developed slash ready? For example, was
being developed up until recently or was
it finalized a while ago?
>> Uh both.
So uh you know we we Fortnite has quite
a long development pipe. Uh and that
pipe has a number of stages that we pass
through. So about a month before
release, it can vary based on like a
launch of a new season, a new chapter or
what we call a point release, but
typically about a month before release,
we have what we call development
complete. And we expect features to be
done at that point. So they're
functional. We could use them
internally. We have a lot of internal
teams, not just the team that developing
a feature, but internal teams who use
these and and verify that they do what
they say on the tin, like does this
work? Not not that it's bug free, but
it's usable. After development complete,
we go through another couple of gates
that are all about bug fixing. Uh
sometimes there is quality of life uh
features or changes for a feature that
we still want to add like maybe clean up
an icon or add tool tips or improve
something, maybe add a missing API. But
a lot of the time from dev complete to
what we call hard lock is about just
fixing bugs. Like we're going to fix
bugs uh low priority bugs, medium high
priority bugs. After hard lock, we get
we go into phase that approaches what we
call pens pencils down. And there we're
just going to fix things that are
blocking us from releasing. So something
like a regression, like a crash, a
performance issue, things that we would
not ship the build with uh is is about
like the last probably 7 to 10 days. And
then we are after pencil's down like
we're really just hammering that build.
like if unless something is going to
crash or be a significant regression, we
will ship that build there even with
some some minor bugs and then uh we go
into we we submit the builds to SER. So
for PlayStation and Micros and uh Xbox
and Switch, we have to provide a build
to those manufacturers for them to
review. That takes a couple of days. So
for 3710, we were you completely hands
off like nobody's touching anything
probably about 5 to 7 days before it
came out. And then for about three three
weeks before that it was really just
fixing bugs of various severity and we
were done about a month before release
in terms of feature work.
And when we're developing features uh
some of the community feedback we got uh
last year was that there was a bit of
instability in our releases. So we also
changed the way we approached our
development and we put major features
into what we call the dotho releases. So
there's the that's the 34 the 35 36 and
then we kept the.1.2.4
for releases to put in bug fixes or
critical fixes or things that came up
into the community. We try to adhere to
that and since we've done that, the
community responded with it that their
releases have been more stable since
we're having more discipline and what
we're adding and when we're adding it.
That way we can fast follow and fix any
critical things that are affecting their
games.
>> Yeah. One of the things that we're doing
a lot particularly after hard lock when
you know the build is usable there's
maybe some bugs but we you know we think
we're in a decent state like we're
playing a lot a lot of games like we can
actually play the content that's live
like you know murder mystery steel brain
we can play it with the upcoming builds
so we're actually having the team QA
members dev members jump in and play the
games to look for regressions you
obviously we don't always get it right
uh you know some of these games we play
a lot some of them we don't play uh as
much and we try and cover a big spectrum
of of games that we test but we're
looking for those regressions
We also have like just a number of
automated tests uh that we go and we uh
effectively cook like kind of push
changes uh new projects to to verify
everything builds with the the latest
backend infrastructure. Uh we have
servers that spin up games and tests
that they load. So we we have a fairly
uh fairly intensive uh QA process both
manual and automated that happens uh
from the hardlock to release uh that
that we go through. And as Jay said,
that's one of the reasons why we try and
uh you'll be hands off of major features
as early as possible and also keep the
what we think might be um as I call them
jell shaking changes for for the big
releases.
>> Yeah, that that totally makes sense. And
I can definitely attest the uh stability
on these releases has gotten uh a lot
better for sure. Um, so for uh in the
case of like an ongoing non-urgent bug
fix for a specific device um and you
have an upcoming version uh about to be
released. So that would probably get put
on to like the next version unless it's
too close to like this version to be
released or
>> there's there's two ways we can approach
that. One of them is to hit the next
version if we possibly can, but we have
to fit it into that structure that
Andrew talked about when we have
development complete um hard lock and
then pencils down. If it's too close and
we cannot guarantee the QA has the time
to look at it, we have a tendency to
push it into the next one. Unless the
issue is affecting, you know, a large
community, we have to weigh each each
issue one by one and determine is this
so painful? Are we willing to take the
little bit of the risk to put it out
there to alleviate some of the pressure?
Because if it's a say a crash that
happens 100% of the time, we'll take the
risk to put the thing out there cuz a
crash is 100% and no one enjoys that. We
also have a second layer where we have
hot fixes and those we are things that
we can issue instantly, you know, to
configure the server to change
something. So when we're developing
features along this, we're also building
in little switches and levers that we
can pull to respond to things so that we
don't have to wait for a dot release. We
can actually go ahead and flip it
immediately and um change the game in
live real time. And we've done that in
the past to alleviate where we introduce
a feature or a tweak or an optimization
and it goes bad when it scales. So then
we'll flip that back and just instantly
fix the problem until we have another
release to then address the issue.
Awesome. Um all right. So let's uh move
on to a another section of questions uh
related to the road map. So uh road map
obviously was changed today. there is an
announcement. Um, obviously delays
happen. I don't think there is a creator
here who hasn't, you know, delayed a
project or an update on their own games.
Um, and one thing as a creator that I
actually really appreciated, uh, today
was the form post with explanations for

Uh, from that, I did have two questions,
though. One of it uh, one of them was

matchmaking. Um it said that it was to
align with upcoming foundational
improvements to the matchmaking service.
Uh are you able to share a little bit
more information on that?
>> Yeah, I mean we we we're basically
replacing our matchmaking service. Uh we
have uh you know what we currently call
MSV1. Uh we're upgrading to uh MSV2. Uh
very imaginatively named. And uh you
know a large part of that change is
actually driven by
our experience last year of making
things like Ballistic. Uh what we found
when we ship ballistic is that our
matchmaking was very oriented around BR
where we're going to put a lot of
players into a match. We pick the player
pool based on a number of
characteristics that all boil down to
ELO to try and get people competitive
games and and then we let them you know
play the game and and uh adjust the ELO
accordingly and games like uh Ballistic
and games we see variety of games from
creators that have more diversity. They
just have different needs. So we've been
building new matchmaking service over
time. uh we are mid migration for some
of our internal projects and some UFN
projects over to it. When we do that
migration, we'll have the capability to
offer new features such as the ability
for creators to set their own
skill-based matchmaking. Uh you know, we
we have two forms of that. one we call
be our proxy where effectively you're
just saying like uh you know
eliminations uh in assists but we're
going to expand that so to have like
more variables that creators can feed
into so to describe like what they think
is how how best to describe skill in
their games but you know I mean long
story short MSV2 wasn't quite ready for
that so we had to move that out and that
resulted in features uh moving out as
well but our goal is that by the end of
this year I think at the end of this
year all our internal products whether
it's Lego Odyssey, BR, OG, new games
will all be on MSV2. And at that point,
we think we'll be able to move a lot
faster with some of those matchmaking
features for uh for creators.
>> Awesome. Yeah. So, um originally, it was
my understanding that the skill-based
matchmaking would um only be available
for like the combat games with uh like
eliminations. So, with this new change,
uh, on release, we're going to, is it
correct to say that we'll be able to see
more ways to utilize skill-based
matchmaking for like the variety games?
Like you said, then
>> we're we're going to start with the what
we call the BR proxy around
eliminations. U, but yes, we we'll be
expanding over time. So, variety games
have greater ability to kind of
communicate the the characteristics they
think are important for their games.
>> Excellent. Jay, did you have anything
there or
>> no?
>> No, nothing. Okay,
>> that's complete. Yeah.
>> Okay, awesome. Uh, then the other one
that I was going to ask about was uh the
spectator improvements and that one uh
was to accommodate a redesigned system
that better aligns with the long-term
development strategy for UEFN. Uh, are
you able to share more on that one?
>> Yeah, so a lot of the spectator
improvements that we're talking about,
we we had these features and we were
putting them into a device. And as we
put them into device, what we realized
is that they weren't they weren't very
flexible to actually achieve the goals
of we looked at as as a if you want to
be broadcasting your game and you want
to be coverage and you want to have
spectators and you want to have
commentators and you want have players
that can observe what are the features
they require. And as we put all those
things in the vice, it became unwieldy
and and the UX just wasn't working out
very well. But then we also have uh
elements in Singap that are lining up
right now that could actually facilitate
all of that. And we said, do we give
this to the community in a way that's
not really going to hit the mark and not
really serve all of their needs, but if
we wait just a short while, all of these
elements are coming online and we'll
give, again, like I talked about in the
in the vehicle example, we're going to
give the community the ability to define
it for themselves, to create the novel
behaviors in the spectating to have all
the components they need in order to do
this their way, customize it for their
game versus being constrained to how the
device is going to dictate to you how it
should work. We're trying to get away
from having devices dictate to our
developers how to make their games and
instead give them the the the primary
libraries they need to do it themselves.
>> Awesome. Well, thank you for sharing
that one. Uh we'll move on to the next
one. So, uh this is something that
actually did stay on the road map for Q3
and I think something that a lot of
people are very excited for and that's
uh thin client. Um and it states that
it's going to be a phased project. Are
you able to share more what it will look
like on release and what will be
gradually added to that?
>> Yes. Yes. Um I think actually one of the
things we were we've been talking about
the team today is actually breaking down
thin client into some clearer roadmap
items to better communicate what exactly
is going to happen. Uh the the root
challenge we have is that Fortnite is a
very large set of content. It's grown
significantly over time and on some
platforms it can be a challenge now for
players to um you know to get in quickly
to games uh particularly if they're
updating patches or they haven't played
Fortnite in a while or perhaps this is
their first visit to Fortnite. And I
think client is really about taking that
data set and separating into separate
what we call products. So the data for
battle royale and Lego UFN games would
be separate and people would download
just what they need to play and then
reducing the minimal set that you have
to get into the the lobby to be as small
as possible so we can actually get into
Fortnite fast. So th those are really
the two the two work streams we're
following like that minimal set and
separate installs per product and then a
variety of technology features to
improve things like streaming. So you
can actually jump in and play a game
with you know medium quality textures
and if you have a high-end device we'll
stream down the high-res textures
instead of having somebody on a high-end
device download the high-res textures
before they play. So we are going to
break that deliverable apart to better
communicate exactly what's happening.
Thin client is one of those projects
that is going to be ongoing. We're going
to be working on thin client probably
this time next year because we just want
to get thinner and thinner. We already
this year brought the Fortnite install
size down I want to say by about 3 GB
which is uh quite significant but we
want to keep going and um later this
year I think we'll be around
uh I don't know like uh 8 gigs but the
most important thing is we won't we'll
be separating the products. So, somebody
who comes in to play a variety game, a
creator game, uh they won't have to
download VR or they won't have to
download Lego Odyssey. They'll just be
downloading the data that's needed to
get into the lobby and then of course
with UFN games, you actually just
download the content that you want to
play there and then and that's the model
we'll follow with VR. It'll look very
similar where if you're coming in to to
play and you choose to be uh play BR,
you'll get a download progress there and
uh then go into the game,
>> right? So um on release it'll be uh you
know
a improvement and either big or small
and then it'll be you know gradually get
better and better as as it goes on.
>> Yeah that's the thing I'm I'm not we're
not doing a good job of communicating
that and it's a challenge like we we've
already shipped a number of elements of
thin client already. Uh we have reduced
the the install size on on the mobile
platforms and PC. There's more to come.
The one of the more not one of the more
notable things we're working on this
year is moving things like outfits out.
So right now if you download Fortnite,
you actually download all the outfits
for players and many of which you will
see on a server when you play people and
many of which more of which you you will
not. So one of the big changes later
this year is we'll just download the
outfits that you have in your locker uh
outfits of the players that are in the
games that you're going to and that'll
be a big size reduction. Uh but I think
that also communicates that you know
there there are many of these things
that over time we we shrink down and and
ship and and we'll keep doing that for
the next year or so.
>> Right. So um for the
players uh who are wearing an outfit you
don't own and you load into a game,
you'll then download
in real time their skin. I guess is that
>> uh
>> how that'll work or
>> if you're wearing an outfit that you
don't I hope you own the outfit if
you're wearing it.
>> No. Yeah. Some somebody in the game with
you. So you join the server.
>> So then then at that time and then um
same like if somebody if you're in a
game already um and somebody joins that

something that they'll just
>> yeah download in real time then?
>> Yeah. There's a number of different
scenarios like actually you stated one
of the ones that we we talk about is
there's a difference between loading
into a game where everybody's joining
the server at the same time and during
matchmaking you have time. We actually
did what we call uh we call it content
on demand or cosmetics on demand and we
do gliders on demand now. So if you're

actually download the gliders while
you're loading in. And if you if you
look carefully you can actually see
sometimes that player distance will
actually pop from a default glider to to
the real one. Um, but we wanted to move
that to all the cosmetics that are in
Fortnite because the biggest amount of

>> Interesting. Yeah, that definitely makes

Uh, all right. Yeah, let's move on to
the uh next piece on the road map I
wanted to ask about and that was the uh
player input experimental. Uh, so
currently we have the input trigger. Uh,
can you share more about what this new
tool will allow us to do that we can't
do with the input trigger?
Okay, so right now the input trigger
device enables use developer to capture
one input and respond to it and that
creates a workflow if you want to
capture three different uh inputs you
need three different devices. Uh and
that was a good start and it allowed it
allowed developers to create um
different player verbs, player actions
in their game responses. The upcoming
release of the player input is intended
to help open up uh development to verse
right you don't need the device and it's
a it's a step towards a richer feature
set because we're going to release um
it's going to function more like
enhanced input and UE we're going to
have sets of input actions so you'll be
able to have sets have jump crouch
sprint weapon primary and you'll be able
to map them and when so you have these
sets of of control inputs then you'll be
able to switch between them which is a
little difficult to do with the input
trigger right now so you can set up
contexts for what's going on so If
you're at a game and you're running
around, you have a set of inputs, but
then if you interact with a panel and
you have some sort of miniame there,
you'll be able to then set change the
inputs there. So now it affects your
little your little miniame as you're
like hacking a panel or something like
that.
>> So that it'll just make it a lot easier
for more complex scenarios. Um, and then
give you more options with that,
>> more control, more control over your
game. really really because that way
you're not having to manage 16 devices
in order to to manage your game. You can
just have the input handled all in verse
in one place and have maybe three sets
for your whole game and that's it. Those
are your input actions for your game and
and that's how it's done in the enhanced
input in UEIE.
>> Yes. All right. Uh thanks for answering
that one. Uh let's go on to the next

uh pushing changes and memory

um and it is what is the philosophy

changes.
So the decision was made to reduce the
calculation time for very large islands.
Uh previously some of you have noticed
some of you developers noticed that it
takes 20 plus minutes to complete memory
calculations. Um that was one of the
primary goals. This system significantly
reduces the time. Some of the data I saw
is it reduced the 20 minute down to
about 3 minutes or so. But please report
back when once this uh when you have
this in your hands, tell us how it's
working for you because it should
produce more consistent results no
matter which platform you're using.
Prior to this, if you were doing the

with the accurate results and control
over your projects. So, you to
